subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Homologizing Language
msgSnippet: It s taken me along time to get around to welcoming you to the group, and giving you at least the honor of a reply - but here it is. I agree with your central
messageBody:
It's taken me along time to get around to welcoming
you to the group, and giving you at least the honor of
a reply - but here it is.

I agree with your central premise that in the future,
for better or worse, "spelling won't matter" just as
it didn't matter 300 years ago - until dictionaries
became God.

But you may be optimistic that we will become one
accent. But we may reach a lowest-common-denominator
of common sounds which would be capturable in
rudimentary QS. (Still, even if we do, there will
still be those (alas, even in high places) that still
say "libary" and "nucular." )

What I find ironic though about the future is that,
since we spend half our lives communicating not with
people, but with computers, rigorous spelling could
yet prove to be of ultimate importance. Today, if I
write a letter to a friend that contains "I thuoght I
wuold see yu," the friend will understand the sense.
If I do a "search" in a computer for that sentence, or
"Ask Jeeves" a question like that, nothing will come
up.

(True, Google can sometimes read your mind and say
"Did you mean XXX?" But could that technology ever be
extended to whole paragraphs and even books?)

What may be possible, I foresee, it that we all have
computers which have learned "our" peculiar spellings,
and we type in "our" QS, and the computer sends a
"standardized" version out, which is translated on the
receiving end into the QS "dialect" that the recipient
uses.

That would indeed be the end of "correct spelling."

And one added advantage of this future - no more
spelling bees>



==============
--- acolyteofmaille <acolyteofmaille@...> wrote:

>
>
> Hello! I'm new to QS, I'm still learning to read it
> fluently (I've
> started taking notes from my book with it though,
> it's not TOO slow
> for the time I have)
>
> I couldn't find anything about any of this, forgive
> me if it's all bee
> said and debated before.
>
> One of the reasons QS was made was to get rid of the
> problems in
> standardized spelling. If QS actually does succeed
> as the standard
> (good luck!) Merrian-Webster and every other
> dictionary maker will
> print dictionaries in QS (or have the word in QS and
> the def. in
> Roman.) People will likely do the same thing with
> that as they do with
> the Roman alphabet. Desire for set structure and
> order is basic part
> of human nature. It is shown in all religion, from
> the Celtic to
> Christianaty and is obviously manifest in the city
> based society
> today. Standardized spelling has been
> instutionalized as one more
> thing to keep in order, and it is very likely that
> it will be passed
> from parents and teachers to children. The
> simplicity and speed of QS
> are probably the only benefits it will hold if it
> ever becomes widely
> used.
> Even if that doesn't happen (maybey especially) one
> dialect may
> eventually become the predominant one by the wide
> circulation of media
> from it. If people start speaking the way they read,
> which is quite
> possible through the whole sub-vocalization process
> that people do
> when reading, then what they read the most may
> change their own
> speech, and in turn change their friends' speech,
> etc. (Was that
> apostraphe right? Stupid bloody possesive
> plurals...) making, most
> likely, the western US accent go almost worldwide.
> Of course New York
> will never change because they still haven't despite
> the attempts
> we've made to fix th I mean the amount of television
> with our accent
> that they have been exposed to, but that is, of
> course, fine (whew,
> that was a close save...) The main British accent
> may also win out,
> there are quite a few books coming to the US from
> there. More likely
> is a mixture, especially since the main TV ones are
> about the same (if
> that guy that NPR rebrodcasts from the BBC is
> representative of the
> majority of Britan.)
> So what do you all think about that hypothesis? It
> would solve the
> copy-cat spelling problem, because we'd all talk the
> same anyway so
> phonetics would work fine in all cases. (Almost.)
> But that would take years and years (or decades and
> decades of
> decadence... sorry, I just had to do that for the
> parrallelism) so the
> dictionary spelling will more likely take back over.
>
> And this has likely been discussed, but what can
> actually be done to
> prevent the spelling problems? I suppose a lot of
> that can be how it
> is presented: spelling doesn't matter, it is made to
> be flexible. I
> think that needs to be emphasized.
>
>
>
>
>
>
>


=====
Bob McBroom Woodstock NY- /byb /mk/brMm /wUdstak /nV /jDk"wun simbel iz az gUd Az anuHD prOvFdid evrIwun atacez H sEm mIniN tM it." - /JPJ /bxnRd /SY

It's taken me along time to get around to welcoming
you to the group, and giving you at least the honor of
a reply - but here it is.

I agree with your central premise that in the future,
for better or worse, "spelling won't matter" just as
it didn't matter 300 years ago - until dictionaries
became God.

But you may be optimistic that we will become one
accent. But we may reach a lowest-common-denominator
of common sounds which would be capturable in
rudimentary QS. (Still, even if we do, there will
still be those (alas, even in high places) that still
say "libary" and "nucular." )

What I find ironic though about the future is that,
since we spend half our lives communicating not with
people,  but with computers, rigorous spelling could
yet prove to be of ultimate importance.  Today, if I
write a letter to a friend that contains "I thuoght I
wuold see yu," the friend will understand the sense.
If I do a "search" in a computer for that sentence, or
"Ask Jeeves" a question like that, nothing will come
up.

(True, Google can sometimes read your mind and say
"Did you mean XXX?" But could that technology ever be
extended to whole paragraphs and even books?)

What may be possible, I foresee, it that we all have
computers which have learned "our" peculiar spellings,
and we type in "our" QS, and the computer sends a
"standardized" version out, which is translated on the
receiving end into the QS "dialect" that the recipient
uses.

That would indeed be the end of "correct spelling."

And one added advantage of this future - no more
spelling bees>
